properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total rainfall amounts of 40 to 50 mm are expected over this area through tomorrow morning. The heavy rain may cause flash floods and pooling on the roads. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Civil Emergency Alert issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan has been extended and remains in effect until rescinded. The public is being reminded to always practice physical distancing of 2 metres when engaging with others. During all Phases of Re-Open Saskatchewan, all public health orders are to be followed and applied in all public and private gatherings.
Expires: 2020-10-28T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-10-14T15:25:36-06:00, 4EF40AA3-5B3B-1E8D-0CB5-32FECF070837
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific low is forecast to move through central BC tonight and track across south-central Alberta Friday. In south-central Alberta, a band of snow associated with this weather system will likely produce accumulations up to 10 cm by Friday afternoon, with higher amounts along the foothills and in the mountain parks. There remains considerable uncertainty as to where the majority of the snow will fall as this low is still off the BC Pacific coast. In southern Alberta, temperatures across the region are expected to initially be well above zero on Friday allowing for possible showers to occur ahead of the snow. As the cold front passes through the region Friday afternoon, temperatures are expected to rapidly fall below zero with snow and strong northerly winds with gusts of 60 to 80 km/h. This abrupt change in weather may lead to hazardous travel conditions, and may occur during the Friday afternoon commute for some southern Alberta communities. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T02:20:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T10:21:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4088804734.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific low pressure system is expected to begin to move into Alberta late tonight, and track through the province on Friday. Significant snowfall associated with this system is expected to begin this evening with accumulations possibly in excess of 25 cm for portions Icefields Parkway by Friday afternoon. Rapidly falling snow with winds gusting near 70 km/h in exposed portions of the highway may lead to poor visibility and local blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T02:21:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T10:22:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1852872348.2020
Area: Highway 93 South - Lake Louise to Saskatchewan River Crossing, Highway 93 North - Jasper to Saskatchewan River Crossing
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A moisture-laden Pacific front will move onto the central coast of B.C. on Thursday. Rain will begin in the morning and becoming heavy late in the day and last through Thursday night. The front will move exit the region early Friday morning. Total rainfall amount of 100 mm is expected over the coastal region and up to 80 mm of rain over the inland sections by Friday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-15T15:03:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-14T23:04:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0696988921.2020
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections, Central Coast - inland sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. LIght winds and high humidity gave dense fog to Kinngait (Cape Dorset) for most of Wednesday. Similar conditions are expected to persist overnight into Thursday afternoon at which point there should be a slight improvement. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-15T20:26:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T04:27:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0280381844.2020
Area: Cape Dorset
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are expected in the lee of Great Slave Lake near and east of the community of Fort Resolution on Thursday and Friday. Snowfall amounts will range significantly depending on where the snow squall sets up, but local total accumulations by Friday evening could exceed 25 cm. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-16T02:12:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T10:13:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2846448530.2020
Area: Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. A moist southeasterly flow off Hudson Bay continues to give poor visibilities in fog at Coral Harbour. Conditions should improve later this morning as slightly drier air works its way into the area. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-15T20:14:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-15T11:16:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0885303338.2020
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada
